title: Sotheby’s Auctioning Artworks by Ugo Rondinone and 14 Others to Benefit Cancer Research
text:
Yellow Red White Blue Mountain sculpture created by Ugo Rondenone in 2019 is being sold at Sotheby's to raise funds for bladder cancer research.

Text size

Led by New York-based Swiss-born artist Ugo Rondinone, 15 contemporary artists have donated their artworks to a benefit auction to be held Thursday at Sotheby’s New York.

Rondinone, 56, a mixed-media artist who is best known for Seven Magic Mountains, installed just south of Las Vegas, donated one of his signature mountain sculpture to the auction, “Stop Bladder Cancer,” as part of Sotheby’s Contemporary Curated.

The piece, measuring 87x49x37 inches with rocks in yellow, red, white, and blue, has a high estimate of $220,000.

The sale could total between $1.5 million and $2 million, says Rondinone, who organized the event to raise awareness for bladder cancer, with which he was diagnosed in May 2017.

“Like most people, I had never heard of it or known someone diagnosed with bladder cancer,” Rondinone says. He was treated by Dr. Douglas Scherr at Weill Cornell Medical College, and by Sept. 2017, his cancer was in remission.

Pat Steir's painting "Reminds Me of Berlin I" is estimated to sell for between $150,000 and $200,000. Courtesy of Sotheby's

Bladder cancer is little-discussed, yet it is the fourth most-diagnosed cancer in the country. Advances have been slow due to lack of funding for research. In the U.S., $600 million is dedicated annually to breast cancer research compared to only $22 million to bladder cancer.

“This is why I decided to be an advocate and fundraiser for bladder cancer research and help to improve the diagnosis and treatment of bladder cancer,” Rondinone says.

The 14 artists who contributed to the auction include Joe Bradley, Carroll Dunham, Latifa Echakhch, John Giorno, Peter Halley, Shara Hughes, Sarah Lucas, Chris Martin, Adam McEwen, Oscar Murillo, Elizabeth Peyton, Bosco Sodi, Pat Steir, and Franz West.

Some artists created new works for the auction, while others donated pieces already on display at galleries. Prices range from $7,000 to $200,000.

Proceeds of the sale will go to the urologic oncology research team, led by Dr. Scherr and Dr. Juan Cubillos-Ruiz at Weill Cornell Medical College.
description: The sale could raise up to $2 million for urologic oncology research at Weill Cornell Medical College
